Award.AwardTitle: Assessing the evolutionary history, taxonomy, and genetic diversity of Pueraria (Fabaceae: tribe Phaseoleae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kudzu (Pueraria montana var. lobata) is a noxious, invasive weed in the U.S. that presents a significant threat to native biodiversity. Since its introduction ~130 years ago, this legume has literally engulfed thousands of square miles and cost millions of dollars in eradication measures. Considering its economic and ecological impact, it is surprisingly understudied. This project will integrate the efforts of citizen scientists, graduate and undergraduate students, and collaborating scientists from four Asian countries to examine the evolutionary history, taxonomy, and genetic diversity of the genus Pueraria in an effort to understand invasiveness in the kudzu species complex and determine how Pueraria species relate to other legumes, including several of economic importance such as soybean (Glycine max) and jicama (Pachyrhizus erosus). Extensive fieldwork will be integrated with genetic and geographic analyses to determine how many introductions of kudzu have taken place in the U.S., from what genetic source(s), and how genetic diversity and interplay within and among Pueraria species and populations have influenced range expansion.

This work will integrate education and research to provide educational opportunities for K-12, post-secondary students and the public through programs connected with Earth Day Activities, A Time for Science Nature Center, citizen science, and an innovative ecotourism venture within Great Smoky Mountain National Park. Results may aid in kudzu eradication efforts by informing management practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the reporting period, Matthew Haynsen, a key contributor to the project, successfully defended his dissertation funded by the grant, entitled ?Where did the ?Vine that Ate the South? originate??. Matthew has worked to understand the population genetics and genomics of kudzu (Pueraria montana var. lobata) and its relatives, specifically to address the questions of where U.S. kudzu originated from across its native Asian range and how many times it was introduced into the United States.  This year, he published work detailing transcriptomics and microsatellite development of markers for population genetics research and showed for the first time using molecular evidence that kudzu likely originated in Japan with secondary potential genetic sources in China. To further this research, Matthew also expanded his microsatellite markers to include 12 markers of two types: those from expressed genes and those from non-expressed regions across the genome. Using this expanded marker set, Matthew tested 40 models detailing possible modes and routes of introduction history of U.S. kudzu. This work is currently in revision for publication to Scientific Reports.

 

In addition, Matthew completed the collection and analysis of an incredible dataset of over 600 samples of kudzu taken across the U.S. and Asia and collected thousands of single nucleotide polymorphisms - markers captured using a reduced representation genomics technique called genotyping-by-sequencing. This dataset has provided critical resolution down to the individual level, enabling a widescale view of the population genomic history of kudzu.  This has provided molecular evidence to aid in the delineation of varieties and species in the kudzu species complex. It has also shown that kudzu was introduced into the U.S. multiple times from multiple genetic sources, mostly from Japan. This work is currently being written up for publication. 

 

PI Egan continued working with understanding the evolutionary history of Pueraria and related genera.  In collaboration with Dr. Mohammad Vatanparast, a former postdoc supported on the grant, over 500 nuclear markers for phylogenomic analysis were created using targeted enrichment methods - markers useable across the order Fabales.  This work has provided critical resources in the form of molecular markers that are useable by researchers the world over for studying legume evolutionary history and genetics.  This marker set was published in a special issue of Applications in Plant Science on phylogenomics.  Using this marker set, Dr. Vatanparast and PI Egan have now captured phylogenomic data for every tribe and subfamily in the legume plant family (Fabaceae) to which Pueraria belongs. This work presents understanding of the early evolutionary history of the legume and how this group became so diverse and evolved into the economically vital plant family it is today.  Publications from this work are ongoing.
